title: S1-epsorth: Prove Œµ-orthogonality of combined basis
description:
**File**: ProjSeminorm/SchneiderReduction.lean, inside exists_epsOrthogonal_basis succ case

**Prerequisite**: S1-basis gives `bF : Module.Basis (Fin (n+1)) ùïú F` with `bF 0 = (bW 0 : F)` and `bF (j+1) = e_lift j`.

**Goal**: Prove `IsEpsOrthogonal Œµ bF`, i.e., `‚àÄ c, ‚Äñ‚àë i, c i ‚Ä¢ bF i‚Äñ ‚â• (1+Œµ)‚Åª¬π * ‚®Ü i, ‚Äñc i‚Äñ * ‚ÄñbF i‚Äñ`.

**Core mathematical argument** (2 cases, ~12 LOC total):

Given `x = ‚àë i, c i ‚Ä¢ bF i = c 0 ‚Ä¢ v‚ÇÄ_F + ‚àë j, c (j+1) ‚Ä¢ e_lift j`:

**Quotient bound**:
- `œÄ(x) = ‚àë j, c(j+1) ‚Ä¢ bQ j` (since œÄ(v‚ÇÄ_F) = 0 and œÄ(e_lift j) = bQ j)
- `‚ÄñœÄ(x)‚Äñ ‚â§ ‚Äñx‚Äñ` (quotient norm ‚â§ original: `Submodule.Quotient.norm_mk_le`)
- `‚ÄñœÄ(x)‚Äñ ‚â• (1+Œ¥)‚Åª¬π * max_j ‚Äñc(j+1)‚Äñ * ‚ÄñbQ j‚Äñ` (Œ¥-orthogonality of bQ, from hbQ)
- `‚ÄñbQ j‚Äñ ‚â• (1+Œ¥)‚Åª¬π * ‚Äñe_lift j‚Äñ` (from lift bound: `‚Äñe_lift j‚Äñ < (1+Œ¥) * ‚ÄñbQ j‚Äñ`)
- Combined: `‚Äñx‚Äñ ‚â• (1+Œ¥)‚Åª¬≤ * max_j ‚Äñc(j+1)‚Äñ * ‚Äñe_lift j‚Äñ`
- Since `(1+Œ¥)¬≤ = 1+Œµ` (from hŒ¥_sq): `‚Äñx‚Äñ ‚â• (1+Œµ)‚Åª¬π * max_j ‚Äñc(j+1)‚Äñ * ‚ÄñbF (j+1)‚Äñ`

**v‚ÇÄ component** (ultrametric case analysis):
- Let `a = c 0 ‚Ä¢ v‚ÇÄ_F`, `b = ‚àë j, c(j+1) ‚Ä¢ e_lift j`, so `x = a + b`.
- **Case A**: `‚Äña‚Äñ ‚â§ ‚Äñx‚Äñ`. Then `‚Äñx‚Äñ ‚â• ‚Äñc 0‚Äñ * ‚Äñv‚ÇÄ_F‚Äñ ‚â• (1+Œµ)‚Åª¬π * ‚Äñc 0‚Äñ * ‚ÄñbF 0‚Äñ`. ‚úì
- **Case B**: `‚Äña‚Äñ > ‚Äñx‚Äñ`. Then `b = x - a`, `‚Äñb‚Äñ ‚â§ max(‚Äñx‚Äñ, ‚Äña‚Äñ) = ‚Äña‚Äñ` (ultrametric).
  Also `a = x - b`, `‚Äña‚Äñ ‚â§ max(‚Äñx‚Äñ, ‚Äñb‚Äñ)`. Since `‚Äña‚Äñ > ‚Äñx‚Äñ`, must have `‚Äña‚Äñ ‚â§ ‚Äñb‚Äñ`.
  Combined with `‚Äñb‚Äñ ‚â§ ‚Äña‚Äñ`: equality `‚Äña‚Äñ = ‚Äñb‚Äñ`.
  Since `‚Äñb‚Äñ ‚â§ max_j ‚Äñc(j+1)‚Äñ * ‚Äñe_lift j‚Äñ` (ultrametric): `‚Äñc 0‚Äñ * ‚Äñv‚ÇÄ_F‚Äñ ‚â§ max_j ...`
  So `max(‚Äñc 0‚Äñ*‚ÄñbF 0‚Äñ, max_j ...) = max_j ...`, and quotient bound handles it. ‚úì

**Assembling the iSup**: The supremum `‚®Ü i, ‚Äñc i‚Äñ * ‚ÄñbF i‚Äñ` equals `max(‚Äñc 0‚Äñ*‚ÄñbF 0‚Äñ, max_j ‚Äñc(j+1)‚Äñ*‚ÄñbF(j+1)‚Äñ)`. In both cases, `‚Äñx‚Äñ ‚â• (1+Œµ)‚Åª¬π * (this max)`. Use `ciSup_le` or `le_ciSup` + case analysis.

title: Document wrong-direction triangle inequality obstruction in DirectApproach.lean
description:
Add detailed documentation to DirectApproach.lean explaining exactly why the direct algebraic approach fails.

The chain of inequalities:
  ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw‚Äñ = ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñ‚àë c_k w_k‚Äñ
             ‚â§ ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚àë |c_k| ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ        [triangle on w ‚Äî correct direction]
             ‚â§ ‚àë_k (‚àë_j |a_{jk}| ¬∑ ‚Äñv_j‚Äñ) ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ   [from u_k = c_k v bound]
             = ‚àë_j ‚Äñv_j‚Äñ ¬∑ (‚àë_k |a_{jk}| ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ)   [swap sums]

We want this ‚â§ ‚àë_j ‚Äñv_j‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw_j‚Äñ, but:
  ‚àë_k |a_{jk}| ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ ‚â• ‚Äñ‚àë_k a_{jk} w_k‚Äñ = ‚Äñw_j‚Äñ

So the intermediate quantity is BIGGER than both sides. We proved A ‚â§ B and B ‚â• C but need A ‚â§ C.

- Ultrametric (non-archimedean): triangle ‚âà equality with d-orthogonal bases, defect ‚Üí 0
- Archimedean: triangle inequality can be arbitrarily lossy, proof is stuck

This analysis explains why h_bidual (enabling the duality approach) is the natural path.

title: S2-limit: Epsilon-to-zero deduction via Bernoulli inequality
description:
File: ProjSeminorm/SchneiderReduction.lean, inside projectiveSeminorm_tprod_ge_ultrametric

Prerequisite: S2-bound provides hbound : forall eps > 0, (1+eps)^{-1}^n * P <= S where P = prod norms, S = projseminorm.

Goal: Deduce P <= S (i.e., ge_iff_le.mpr).

APPROACH: le_of_forall_pos_lt_add + Bernoulli inequality.

STEP 1 - Case n=0 (~2 LOC):
  by_cases hn : Fintype.card iota = 0
  If n=0: (1+eps)^0 = 1, so hbound gives 1 * P <= S directly.
  specialize hbound 1 one_pos; simpa [hn] using hbound

STEP 2 - Case n>0, use le_of_forall_pos_lt_add (~3 LOC):
  apply le_of_forall_pos_lt_add
  intro delta hdelta

STEP 3 - Choose eps and derive P < S + delta (~10 LOC):
  Key chain: from hbound with specific eps, get (1+eps)^{-n} * P <= S.
  So P = (1+eps)^{-n}*P + (1-(1+eps)^{-n})*P <= S + (1-(1+eps)^{-n})*P.
  Need (1-(1+eps)^{-n})*P < delta.

  BERNOULLI BOUND: one_add_mul_le_pow gives 1 + n*a <= (1+a)^n for a >= -2.
  Apply with a = -eps/(1+eps) (which is in (-1,0] for eps>0, so >= -2):
    1 - n*eps/(1+eps) <= (1+eps)^{-n}
  So 1 - (1+eps)^{-n} <= n*eps/(1+eps) < n*eps.
  So (1-(1+eps)^{-n})*P < n*eps*P.

  CHOOSE eps: take eps = delta / (n * P + 1) (avoids division by zero).
  Then n*eps*P = n*delta*P/(n*P+1) < delta. QED.

  Actually simpler: take eps = delta / (2 * n * P) when P > 0 (which holds since all norms positive and nonempty).
  Then n*eps*P = delta/2 < delta.
  Need: P > 0: from hm (all norms nonzero) + Finset.prod_pos.

- one_add_mul_le_pow: 1 + n*a <= (1+a)^n for a >= -2 (Bernoulli)
